As we continue to recover from the COVID crisis, we must ensure that Black business owners aren't left behind. 

The Committee is working to promote policies that drive equitable recovery and prioritize the business most impacted by this crisis. 

https://smallbusiness.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=3578

Despite these barriers, Black entrepreneurs are dynamic. 

An astounding 17% of Black women are in the process of starting or running new businesses, the highest of any group. 

https://hbr.org/2021/05/black-women-are-more-likely-to-start-a-business-than-white-men

But Black business owners have long faced steep obstacles.

According to the Federal Reserve, over half of the loan apps submitted by black-owned businesses were denied in 2014, 50% more than their white counterparts.

https://www.federalreserve.gov/publications/2017-september-availability-of-credit-to-small-businesses.htm

COVID devastated black-owned businesses. 

Black business ownership rates dropped 41% between February and April 2020, the largest rate of any racial group. 

Black entrepreneurs also had a harder time accessing critical relief programs than their peers. 

https://www.wsj.com/articles/black-owned-businesses-hit-especially-hard-by-coronavirus-pandemic-study-finds-11596558754
As we celebrate emancipation, we must recognize the impact of Black entrepreneurs and the progress we still have to make to achieve equity in the #SmallBiz economy.

As we work our way out of the pandemic and celebrate #Juneteenth today, it is important to remember that it will take all Americans to overcome the deeply entrenched social and economic inequality that Black Americans face in the United States.
All of these ideas are part of the broad basket of policy solutions that will be required to achieve more equity.

To start: 
-forming  a commission to study reparations
-implementing baby bonds and other wealth-building programs 
-improving financial integration  and
-reshaping the tax code so that it no longer perpetuates income and wealth disparities
The focus on individuals achieving their own social mobility via education and financial literacy is insufficient in addressing the racial wealth gap. Structural solutions are required.

Black women in particular struggle to receive equitable outcomes for similar choices. Because of the ‚Äúdouble wage gap,‚Äù they make 63 cents on average for every dollar a white man makes. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E4K2CvjXwAQG_ig.jpg

Black Americans face discrimination in the labor market.  The Black-white ratio of unemployment has remained close to 2:1 since data was first collected in the 70‚Äôs. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E4K1-GVXEAMCSdr.jpg

While measures of progress like educational attainment have gone up for Black Americans in the last 30 years, the median wealth gap between Black and white households has changed very little. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E4K1wNTWUAIKGgI.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E4K16isWYAEgK92.jpg

Even taking education into account,  Black Americans with a bachelor‚Äôs degree have 6x less wealth than white Americans, and Black Americans with a post-grad degree haves 5x less wealth. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E4K1rKJXoAY7Diq.jpg

Follow below for a quick dive into how Black Americans are faring in sectors of our economy: 

Black Americans are often told that getting a college education is the best way to move closer to the American dream and close the racial wealth gap.

The facts don‚Äôt bear this out.
Saturday, June 19th, is a day for celebration, but also a time to recognize the work that remains to address the legacies of slavery and Jim Crow in the economy.
The #Juneteenth National Independence Day Act signed yesterday establishes a federal holiday commemorating when Union troops finally had sufficient numbers to enforce emancipation across the country.
